channel.title: JBoss Issue Tracker
channel.description: This file is an XML representation of an issue

item.title: [WFLY-2623] Unable to change process-id mechanism from process-id-uuid to process-id-socket-binding on transaction
item.description:
https://bugzilla.redhat.com/show_bug.cgi?id=1036739
process-id mechanism can not be changed from process-id-uuid to process-id-socket-binding.

The following ERROR occurred at JBoss start-up:

ERROR [org.jboss.as.controller.management-operation] (ServerService Thread Pool -- 44) JBAS014613: Operation ("add") failed - address: ([("subsystem" => "transactions")]) - failure description: "JBAS014746: process-id-uuid may not be null"

The root reason is it does not check the PROCESS_ID_UUID if defined when booting the coreEnvironment service in TransactionSubsytemAdd.
item.summary: Unable to change process-id mechanism from process-id-uuid to process-id-socket-binding on transaction

status.description: The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are not closed can be reopened.

comments.comment: Hayk Hovsepyan has made a fix with adding the default false value for PROCESS_ID_UUID
Amos Feng <zfeng@redhat.com> changed the Status of bug 1036739 from NEW to POST
Kabir Khan <kkhan@redhat.com> changed the Status of bug 1036739 from POST to MODIFIED
Paul Gier <pgier@redhat.com> changed the Status of bug 1036739 from MODIFIED to ON_QA
Ondrej Chaloupka <ochaloup@redhat.com> changed the Status of bug 1036739 from ON_QA to VERIFIED
mark yarborough <myarboro@redhat.com> changed the Status of bug 1036739 from VERIFIED to CLOSED

Works on WildFly 8.2, but fails on WildFly 9.x and latest WildFly 10.0.0.Beta2-SNAPSHOT.

After creating the following socket binding 

[standalone@localhost:9990 /] /socket-binding-group=standard-sockets/socket-binding=txn-socket-process-id:add(port=4714)
 
{"outcome" => "success"}

any combination to change process-id mechanism from process-id-uuid to process-id-socket-binding fails:

Batch / Order 1

 
[standalone@localhost:9990 /] batch
 
[standalone@localhost:9990 / #] /subsystem=transactions:write-attribute(name=process-id-uuid,value=false)
 
[standalone@localhost:9990 / #] /subsystem=transactions:write-attribute(name=process-id-socket-binding,value=txn-socket-process-id)
 
[standalone@localhost:9990 / #] run-batch -v
 
The batch failed with the following error (you are remaining in the batch editing mode to have a chance to correct the error): {"WFLYCTL0062: Composite operation failed and was rolled back. Steps that failed:" => {"Operation step-2" => "WFLYCTL0105: process-id-uuid is invalid in combination with process-id-socket-binding"}}

Batch / Order 2

 
[standalone@localhost:9990 /] batch
 
[standalone@localhost:9990 / #] /subsystem=transactions:write-attribute(name=process-id-socket-binding,value=txn-socket-process-id)
 
[standalone@localhost:9990 / #] /subsystem=transactions:write-attribute(name=process-id-uuid,value=false)
 
[standalone@localhost:9990 / #] run-batch -v
 
The batch failed with the following error (you are remaining in the batch editing mode to have a chance to correct the error): {"WFLYCTL0062: Composite operation failed and was rolled back. Steps that failed:" => {"Operation step-2" => "WFLYCTL0105: process-id-uuid is invalid in combination with process-id-socket-binding"}}

Single Commands

 
[standalone@localhost:9990 /] /subsystem=transactions:write-attribute(name=process-id-uuid,value=false)
 
{
 
    "outcome" => "failed",
 
    "failure-description" => "WFLYTX0025: Either process-id-uuid must be 'true' or  process-id-socket-binding must be defined.",
 
    "rolled-back" => true
 
}
 
[standalone@localhost:9990 /] /subsystem=transactions:write-attribute(name=process-id-socket-binding,value=txn-socket-process-id)
 
{
 
    "outcome" => "failed",
 
    "failure-description" => "WFLYCTL0105: process-id-uuid is invalid in combination with process-id-socket-binding",
 
    "rolled-back" => true
 
}

I think we add some checking codes for "process-id-uuid" and "process-id-socket-binding". So you need to undefine the process-id-uuid and then set the process-id-socket-binding. The following steps work on my machine.

[standalone@localhost:9990 /] batch
 
[standalone@localhost:9990 / #] /socket-binding-group=standard-sockets/socket-binding=txn-socket-process-id:add(port=4714)
 
[standalone@localhost:9990 / #] /subsystem=transactions:undefine-attribute(name=process-id-uuid)
 
[standalone@localhost:9990 / #] /subsystem=transactions:write-attribute(name=process-id-socket-binding,value=txn-socket-process-id)
 
[standalone@localhost:9990 / #] run-batch --verbose
 
{
 
    "outcome" => "success",
 
    "result" => {
 
        "step-1" => {"outcome" => "success"},
 
        "step-2" => {
 
            "outcome" => "success",
 
            "response-headers" => {"operation-requires-reload" => true}
 
        },
 
        "step-3" => {
 
            "outcome" => "success",
 
            "response-headers" => {"operation-requires-reload" => true}
 
        }
 
    },
 
    "response-headers" => {"process-state" => "reload-required"}
 
}
 
[standalone@localhost:9990 /] reload

Thanks for the clarification. What would I need to execute to change back to uuid? The following fails:

[standalone@localhost:9990 /] batch
 
[standalone@localhost:9990 / #] /subsystem=transactions:undefine-attribute(name=process-id-socket-binding)
 
[standalone@localhost:9990 / #] /subsystem=transactions:write-attribute(name=process-id-uuid,value=true)
 
[standalone@localhost:9990 / #] run-batch -v
 
The batch failed with the following error (you are remaining in the batch editing mode to have a chance to correct the error): {"WFLYCTL0062: Composite operation failed and was rolled back. Steps that failed:" => {"Operation step-1" => "WFLYCTL0155: process-id-socket-binding may not be null"}}

I have been looking at this during EAP DR8 testing and I put my "UX feelings" as description of WFLY-5126 (I've put it as duplication issue as this one in fact covers the trouble that I described in WFLY-5126)

As have been discussed here it's possible to set process-id-uuid or process-id-socket-binding in either way.

batch
 
/subsystem=transactions:undefine-attribute(name=process-id-uuid)
 
/subsystem=transactions:write-attribute(name=process-id-socket-binding, value="txn-status-manager")
 
run-batch


/subsystem=transactions:write-attribute(name=process-id-uuid, value=true)

This is a bit confusing how it's done. Could this be enhanced from user point of view?

My ideas are like
maybe composite operation could not be demanded and /subsystem=transactions:write-attribute(name=process-id-socket-binding, value="txn-status-manager") could undefine process-id-uuid automatically as this behaves from other setting direction. Or maybe description of failures could be changed to inform user that batch operation is needed.
And on the other hand composite operation when setting process-id-uuid and unsetting process-id-socket-binding should not fail I think.
Last thing is that :write-attribute(name=process-id-uuid, value=false in composite operation should not fail.

Most of the forms in the management console are automatically generated based on the attribute metadata from the :read-resource-description operation. This works pretty well for simple attributes / resources.

However complex dependencies between attributes like process-id-uuid and process-id-socket-binding cannot be addressed with this approach.

Switching between UUID and socket binding should be provided as custom operations. The attributes should be read-only to reflect the current state. Other management clients like the CLI would benefit from this approach as well. IMO its way too complicated to switch back and forth using default operations.

yeah, I agree that it looks like a bit confusing.

process-id-uuid and process-id-socket-binding are alternatives as we have some complex logic to check them.
1) There is either process-id-uuid or process-id-socket-binding setting
2) It should fail if you set both of them
3) It should fail if you set none of them

undefined the process-id-socket-binding fails with WFLYCTL0155 because it has no default value.

So how can I switch from UUID to socket binding then? Obviously the batch in https://issues.jboss.org/browse/WFLY-2623?focusedCommentId=13099282&page=com.atlassian.jira.plugin.system.issuetabpanels:comment-tabpanel#comment-13099282 doesn't work.

To switch from socket binding to uuid you need to run just command as non-composite operation

/subsystem=transactions:write-attribute(name=process-id-uuid, value=true)

It will unset the socket binding automatically at the background. Tested with EAP 7.0.0.DR8 (WFLY.Beta1)

Thanks. Works on my machine.

One last comment: After switching between UUID and socket binding (and vice versa) :read-resource fails until :reload is executed. I guess that's on purpose. In that case I need to add some extra code to handle this in the console.

Again having custom operations would really help to make the user's life easier. Plus it would save a lot of extra handling / code in the console.

So I think
Option 1: switching between uuid and socket-binding by using batch with undefine the first one then write the second one.
It needs to fix to add the default value on the process-id-socket-binding
Option 2: switching between uuid and socket-binding by using the single write-attribute operation
It needs to fix to remove the uuid after setting the socket-binding value
Option 3: provide the custom operations
I'm not sure how to add and dose it need to work on the transaction subsystem ?

If I can I would vote for the third option. It seems to me the most meaningful.

One operation that I'm aware of is the enable and disable operation on datasource. Maybe it could be inspiration (in case, not sure).

/subsystem=datasources/data-source=ExampleDS:enable()
 
/subsystem=datasources/data-source=ExampleDS:disable()

Then there is attribute /subsystem=datasources/data-source=ExampleDS:read-attribute(name=enabled) which shows the actual value. That attribute should be read-only as Harald mentioned. Thought the enable thing could not be the best example as Stefano plans to remove those operations (WFLY-4294, WFLY-4050)

/subsystem=datasources/data-source=ExampleDS:read-operation-description(name=enable)
 
/subsystem=datasources/data-source=ExampleDS:read-resource-description()

Ondra Chaloupka I think it makes sense and can you raise the other issue for this custom operations ?
Harald Pehl are you happy to close this issue ?
Yes, closing the issue it ok for me.
Amos Feng Sure. Issue created https://issues.jboss.org/browse/WFLY-5139

customfieldvalues.customfieldvalue:
1) bin/standalone.sh
2) bin/jboss-cli.sh --connect and execute the following 

/socket-binding-group=standard-sockets/socket-binding=txn-socket-process-id/:add(port=4714)
 
/subsystem=transactions:write-attribute(name=process-id-uuid,value=false)
 
/subsystem=transactions:write-attribute(name=process-id-socket-binding,value=txn-socket-process-id)

3) restart the jboss-as
